question: Question_04
statement:
Define the sum of divisors function $\displaystyle \sigma(n)$ and number
of divisors function $\displaystyle \tau(n)$. Show that there is no
positive integer \emph{n} with $\displaystyle \phi(n) = 14.$
sols:
First,

$\displaystyle \sigma(n) = \sum_{d \mid n} d$

and

$\displaystyle \tau(n) = \sum_{d \mid n}1$

gives the required definitions.

For the last part, we proceed by a contradiction and suppose that
$\displaystyle \phi(n) = 14$ for some integer \emph{n}.

As stated in the hint, we have

$\displaystyle \phi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n}p^{\alpha_{p}-1}(p-1) = 14$.

where $\displaystyle n = \prod p^{\alpha_{p}}$. Now every odd prime
present in the factorization of \emph{n} contributes a power of two to
$\displaystyle \phi(n)$ due to the $\displaystyle (p-1)$ factor. Thus,
there can be at most one odd prime dividing \emph{n}, say
$\displaystyle p$.

If $\displaystyle p$ occurs to a power of two, then because it divides
the left hand side, it must divide 14 and so must be 7. The prime
$\displaystyle p$ cannot occur to a third power or higher since
otherwise there are two factors of $\displaystyle p$ on the left and at
most one on the right. However $\displaystyle \phi(7^{2}) = 42 > 14$ and
so the power must be 1. Thus $\displaystyle n = 2^{\alpha} p$ for some
$\displaystyle \alpha$. Notice that as the phi-function is
multiplicative, we have that

$\displaystyle 14 = \phi(n) = \phi(2^{\alpha})\phi(p) = 2^{\alpha-1}(p-1)$

(or we have that $\displaystyle \phi(n) = p-1$ if no power of 2 divides
n)

Thus, as $\displaystyle p-1$ is even, we have that
$\displaystyle \alpha = 1$ (or \emph{n} is odd) and further that
$\displaystyle p = 15$ which is not a prime. This is a contradiction and
hence this equation has no solution.
hints:
For the last part, use the fact that

$\displaystyle \phi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n}p^{\alpha-1}(p-1) = 14$.

where $\displaystyle n = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n} p^{\alpha}$ and
where we recall that $\displaystyle p^{\alpha} \parallel n$ means that
$\displaystyle p^{\alpha}$ fully divides \emph{n} (that is, this is the
highest power of \emph{p} that divides \emph{n}).
